questions.text: A 36-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was an unrestrained passenger. He has acute myeloid leukemia and is currently receiving chemotherapy. On arrival, his temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 63/min, respirations are 10/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and sluggish. There are multiple bruises over the face, trunk, and right upper and lower extremities. There is a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over his right cheek. He does not respond to any commands but does groan. Painful stimuli cause him to open his eyes and withdraw all extremities. There are decreased breath sounds over the right lung base. There is tenderness to palpation over the left chest wall. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and shows diffuse tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. There is swelling of the right elbow and wrist. The right lower extremity is shorter than the left lower extremity. There are 2 lacerations around 2 cm (0.8 in) each on the right leg. The right knee is swollen. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: CT scan of the head and neck

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The patient does have abdominal tenderness and will require some form of assessment for intraabdominal bleeding such as a FAST scan, but only after implementing a very critical measure from the advanced trauma life support-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

B) INCORRECT:

A pelvic binder would address critical blood loss and help stabilize potential pelvic fractures, but it would not address the primary concern as dictated by the ABCDE approach to treating trauma patients.

C) INCORRECT:

An intercostal chest tube is indicated for treating tension pneumothorax (TP). The patient has decreased breath sounds at the right lung base, a finding associated with TP, but does not show other signs like tachypnea, tracheal deviation away from the affected lung, or jugular venous distention, making TP an unlikely diagnosis. The first priority for this patient with a GCS score of 8 is another very critical measure of the ATLS-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

D) INCORRECT:

The patient will require imaging of the head to assess intracranial bleeding and other damage to the head and neck area. Imaging of the neck is especially important for assessment of cervical spine integrity. However, head and neck imaging can take place only after implementing a very critical measure from the advanced trauma life support-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

E) INCORRECT:

This patient will need evaluation of his extremities for bone and soft tissue damage, but only after implementation of a very critical measure from the advanced trauma life support-recommended approach to trauma resuscitation (following the ABCDE approach).

F) CORRECT:

As a general rule, patients with a GCS score of 8 or below as a result of traumatic brain injury require intubation and mechanical ventilation to protect the airway and ensure adequate ventilation. Such patients are at risk of airway obstruction via aspiration because they lack a gag reflex. They are also at risk of hypoxia from poor ventilation because brainstem damage can decrease the respiratory drive.
questions.hint: This patient has a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of 8 (groans = 2; opens eyes to pain = 2; withdraws extremities to pain = 4).

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 1 hour after falling off his bike and landing head-first on the pavement. His mother says that he did not lose consciousness but has been agitated and complaining about a headache since the event. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. There is a large bruise on the anterior scalp and several superficial abrasions on both hands and knees. Examination, including neurologic examination, shows no other abnormalities. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows a nondepressed linear skull fracture with a 2-mm separation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Although asymptomatic patients with relatively small (< 3 mm) linear, nondepressed skull fractures may be sent home without further management, those with signs of potentially elevated ICP require further inpatient observation. Other indications for inpatient observation include evidence of traumatic brain injury on imaging (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage), signs of physical abuse, or caregivers who are unreliable or unable to return if neurological deficits develop within 24 hours after release.

B) INCORRECT:

Asymptomatic patients with relatively small, linear skull fractures (< 3 mm) without depression may be sent home if a caregiver is able to properly monitor the patient for signs of altered consciousness or other new neurological symptoms for 24 hours. This patient exhibits signs of potential elevated ICP (e.g., headache, agitated state), which requires another action at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

Contacting child protective services is not necessary because this patient does not have identifiable signs of physical abuse (e.g., subdural hemorrhages, buckle fractures, fractures showing different states of healing on x-ray) and thus his injury was most likely accidental.

D) INCORRECT:

A brain MRI is a costly imaging modality that would not provide additional useful information for the management of this patient based on his current presentation. It may be indicated for patients in which the clinical picture is inconsistent with the CT scan findings (e.g., a patient with a worsening condition despite a normal CT scan), or if diffuse axonal injury may be suspected (acceleration/deceleration injuries or rotational injuries). The primary clinical manifestation of diffuse axonal injury is loss of consciousness; an MRI may be indicated in this child if he develops any deficits in consciousness.

E) INCORRECT:

CT angiography would be indicated for the evaluation of patients with cerebral aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations but does not play a role in the management of patients with acute head trauma.
questions.hint: This patient presents with agitation and headache, both of which can be signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP).

questions.text: A 24-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was a restrained driver. On arrival, he is alert and oriented. His pulse is 112/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. There is a 3-cm laceration over the forehead and multiple bruises over the trunk. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The right knee is swollen and tender; range of motion is limited by pain. Infusion of 0.9% saline is begun and intravenous acetaminophen is administered. Two hours later, blood-tinged fluid spontaneously drains from both nostrils and is made worse by leaning forward. On a piece of gauze, it shows up as a rapidly expanding clear ring of fluid surrounding blood. Further evaluation of this patient over the next 24 hours is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Basilar skull fracture can be associated with cranial nerve palsies. Anterior basilar skull fracture can cause cranial nerve (CN) I palsies, as well as palsies in CN V, VI, VII, or VIII. However, CN XII exits the skull at the hypoglossal canal of the occipital bone (in the posterior fossa) and thus is associated with posterior basilar skull fractures, not anterior basilar skull fractures. Additionally, most cranial nerve palsies associated with basilar skull fracture are not present until 1–3 days after injury, because the palsy is the result of compression or contusion of the nerve, which does not occur acutely. If a nerve is transected by trauma (which is uncommon), then the palsy would be present immediately.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with CSF rhinorrhea, which is a classic sign of anterior basilar skull fracture. The positive halo sign confirms that the leakage contains CSF. Bilateral periorbital ecchymosis (“raccoon eyes”) is another typical sign of basilar skull fracture involving the anterior cranial fossa. "Raccoon eyes" is not seen immediately after an injury but rather develops after 1–3 days.

If basilar skull fracture is suspected, the next best steps in management are noncontrast CT scan of the head to confirm the diagnosis and neurosurgical consultation.
Image Description:

Face of a 54-year-old man after a fall on the back of his head 2 days earlier

Bilateral, symmetrical, dark purplish discoloration around the eye sockets is visible.

This appearance, also referred to as "raccoon eyes," is a typical sign of basilar skull fractures involving the anterior fossa and typically develops 1–3 days after injury. Nontraumatic causes include neuroblastoma, plasma cell proliferative disorders (e.g., amyloidosis), and hematological malignancies. Periorbital ecchymosis may occur unilaterally or bilaterally.

C) INCORRECT:

Upper cheek numbness is caused by damage to the infraorbital nerve, which is a complication of orbital fracture. Basilar skull fracture can in rare cases cause facial numbness by damaging cranial nerve V, but this would be seen in middle cranial fossa fracture. This patient's CSF rhinorrhea is indicative of anterior fossa fracture.

D) INCORRECT:

Trismus is most commonly associated with tetanus but may also be caused by zygomatic arch or mandibular fracture. Other signs of zygomatic arch or mandibular fracture include facial paresthesias, intraoral lacerations, and orbital edema. However, this patient has signs of anterior basilar skull fracture, not zygomatic or mandibular fracture, making trismus unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Carotid artery dissection is a rare complication of basilar skull fracture, specifically fractures involving injury to the carotid canal. Another finding would be much more likely. Additionally, this patient's CSF rhinorrhea suggests damage to the anterior fossa, while the carotid canal is in the middle fossa.

F) INCORRECT:

Retroauricular ecchymosis (“Battle sign”) involves the petrous part of the temporal bone specifically and is a classic sign of basilar skull fracture. However, petrous temporal fracture would cause CSF otorrhea, not rhinorrhea.
questions.hint: This man has blood-tinged fluid draining from his nose after trauma that shows a halo sign (rapidly expanding clear ring of fluid surrounding blood), indicating cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) rhinorrhea. The most likely explanation is a basilar skull fracture of the anterior cranial fossa.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 3-day history of nonbloody vomiting and poor feeding. He transitioned to pureed vegetables 10 days ago. Over the past 2 weeks, he has become increasingly irritable and within the past day has taken more daytime naps and appears much less responsive and interactive. His mother denies any history of fever or trauma at home. He has not received any vaccinations as his parents believe he is already healthy and does not need them. He spends most of the day with a babysitter while both parents are at work. He appears lethargic. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Auscultation of the heart and lungs shows no abnormalities. The anterior fontanelle is tense and bulging. Fundoscopic examination shows bilateral retinal hemorrhage. A complete blood count shows a leukocyte count of 10,000/mm3. An x-ray of the chest shows healing fractures of the 2nd and 3rd right ribs. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tumors of the posterior fossa (e.g., juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma) are the most common pediatric primary brain tumors. A mass in the posterior fossa could gradually lead to altered mental status and could also increase intracranial pressure in a 7-month-old child to the extent that the anterior fontanelle would be tense and bulging. However, increased intracranial pressure would more likely be associated with papilledema on fundoscopic examination than retinal hemorrhages. In addition, this child's healing rib fractures should raise suspicion of a traumatic etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

The skeletal manifestations of vitamin D deficiency, rickets, can also be associated with pathological fractures of the ribs and other locations. However, this child has no other signs of bony deformities or fractures, and pathological fracture at an isolated location is less common in vitamin D deficiency. In addition, vitamin D deficiency is not associated with this patient's other findings of retinal hemorrhage, bulging anterior fontanelle, and altered mental status.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacterial meningitis could lead to altered mental status, which might manifest in the irritability and lethargy seen in this child. Before the anterior fontanelle closes (at 18–24 months of age), increased intracranial pressure (e.g., due to meningitis) can cause it to bulge. Children who are septic from meningitis may also rarely present with retinal hemorrhages. However, bacterial meningitis typically presents more acutely, in a matter of hours or days. Additionally, this child is afebrile and has a normal white blood cell count, both of which are unexpected findings in children with meningitis, particularly in meningitis due to bacterial pathogens.

D) INCORRECT:

An epidural hematoma could also lead to irritability, lethargy, signs of increased intracranial pressure, including a bulging anterior fontanelle, and retinal hemorrhage in rare cases. However, retinal hemorrhages are less frequently associated with epidural hemorrhage than other etiologies. Additionally, an epidural hematoma would likely present more acutely and with other physical examination findings, such as a visible hematoma or swelling in the area of head trauma, which this patient does not have. While this diagnosis cannot be excluded completely, a different option is more likely.

E) CORRECT:

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI) is commonly seen in children with shaken baby syndrome (SBS). In such cases, DAI is most likely caused by rotational acceleration-deceleration forces inflicted by violent shaking of the infant and by secondary hypoxia (e.g., due to transient apnea). Long-term deficits resulting from SBS include sight, hearing, and speech impairment. SBS has an extremely high mortality rate, with approx. 25% of affected children dying as a result of sustained injuries. Cranial CT scan in patients with SBS often shows additional brain injuries such as chronic subdural hematoma (which would explain this patient's subacute presentation over 2 weeks), subarachnoid bleeding, and/or diffuse punctate parenchymal hemorrhages.

F) INCORRECT:

Osteogenesis Imperfecta (OI) is caused by defective synthesis of type I collagen. Patients with this disorder are prone to pathologic fractures and may present with rib fractures. Skull fractures and associated intracranial bleeding are more common in children with OI and could cause altered mental status in the absence of a history of significant trauma. However, patients with OI often have blue sclera, hearing loss, and joint laxity, which are not present in this patient. Additionally, while OI is often hard to differentiate from child abuse, the low prevalence of OI makes child abuse more likely in the general population.

G) INCORRECT:

Many rodenticides contain long-acting anticoagulants, such as super warfarin. Ingestion of these rodenticides can lead to coagulopathy and pathological bleeding, usually beginning about 24 hours after ingestion. This coagulopathy could cause both retinal hemorrhages and intracranial bleeding leading to altered mental status, as seen in this patient. However, coagulopathy would likely also manifest in other locations, causing gastrointestinal bleeding, ecchymoses, epistaxis, and hematuria. This patient does not have any other signs of pathological bleeding, nor would this etiology explain this patient's associated rib fractures.
questions.hint: Retinal hemorrhage and associated rib fractures in a 7-month-old infant should raise concern for child abuse.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency room 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which he was the restrained driver. His pulse is 55/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 155/70 mm Hg. Breath sounds are shallow. Examination shows multiple head contusions and a 3 cm x 3-cm soft hematoma on his left temporal region. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated, and infusion of 0.9% saline is started. A CT scan of the head shows a left-sided temporal bone fracture with an associated small left subarachnoid hemorrhage. He is taken to the neurosurgical intensive care unit for further management. The decision to intubate this patient was most likely based on which of the following combination of findings?



Eye opening
Verbal response
Motor response



A
To verbal command
Oriented
Obeys commands


B
To pain
Incomprehensible sounds
Abnormal flexion


C
To verbal command
Confused speech
Localizes pain


D
To pain
Incomprehensible words
Obeys commands


E
Open spontaneously
Inappropriate words
Withdraws from pain
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A trauma patient who opens their eyes to verbal command, is oriented, and obeys commands would receive a GCS score of 14 (3 for eye opening, 5 for verbal response, and 6 for motor response). A GCS score of 14 indicates only mild head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation

B) CORRECT:

A patient who opens their eyes to pain, makes incomprehensible sounds, and has decorticate posture (or abnormal flexion) would receive a total GCS score of 7 (2 for eye-opening, 2 for a verbal response, and 3 for motor response). GCS assessment is part of the primary trauma survey in any trauma patient to evaluate neurological status, consciousness, and degree of brain injury. A GCS score of ≤ 8 indicates severe brain injury with a decreasing level of consciousness, which requires emergency endotracheal intubation to protect the patient's airway and reduce the risk of aspiration of gastric contents.

See “Glasgow coma scale” table.

C) INCORRECT:

A trauma patient who opens their eyes to verbal command, speaks confused or disoriented words, and localizes pain would receive a GCS score of 12 (3 for eye-opening, 4 for verbal response, and 5 for motor response). A GCS score of 12 indicates only moderate head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation.

D) INCORRECT:

A trauma patient who opens their eyes to pain and makes incomprehensible sounds but obeys commands would receive a GCS score of 10 (2 for eye-opening, 2 for verbal response, and 6 for motor response). A GCS score of 10 indicates moderate head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation.

E) INCORRECT:

A trauma patient who opens their eyes spontaneously, speaks inappropriate words, and withdraws from pain would receive a GCS score of 11 (4 for eye-opening, 3 for verbal response, and 4 for motor response). A GCS score of 11 indicates moderate head injury and would not be an indication for endotracheal intubation.
questions.hint: In cases of acute trauma, a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score ≤ 8 is an indication for urgent endotracheal intubation.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being hit by a car while crossing the street. He had a left-sided tonic-clonic seizure and one episode of vomiting while being transported to the hospital. On arrival, he is not oriented to person, place, or time. Physical examination shows flaccid paralysis of all extremities. A CT scan of the head is shown. This patient's symptoms are most likely the result of a hemorrhage in which of the following structures?

choices.text: Between the dura mater and the arachnoid mater
Between the skull and the dura mater
Between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intraventricular hemorrhage typically occurs secondary to intracerebral or subarachnoid hemorrhage but can arise from rare vascular malformations. As with other intracranial bleeds, the characteristic presentation involves sudden onset of headache, vomiting, and altered level of consciousness. However, imaging of the head would show accumulation of blood within the ventricular system, which is not seen on this patient's head CT.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

A large hematoma (red overlay) accompanied by edema (green overlay) and mild mass effect involves the right basal ganglia and cerebral parenchyma. A small left basal ganglia hemorrhage (blue overlay) is also present. Hemorrhage has extended into the ventricular system (yellow overlay). Portions of a right ventricular stent (white arrows) are visible.

B) INCORRECT:

Shearing of bridging veins causes subdural hemorrhage, which is characterized by bleeding between the dura mater and arachnoid mater. Patients may present with headache and signs of increased ICP immediately following head trauma, as is the case here. However, head CT would show a high-density crescent-shaped collection (in acute cases) or a hypodense crescent-shaped collection (in chronic and subacute cases) across the hemispheric convexity, which crosses the suture lines.
Image Description:

CT head (without IV contrast; axial section; brain window) of a patient with a history of trauma

A large acute subdural hematoma is visible as a hyperdense crescent-shaped lesion along the lateral aspect of the left hemisphere (red overlay). It is accompanied by an extracranial soft tissue hematoma (hatched red overlay). There is extensive hypodense left cerebral edema (gray overlay), with sulcal effacement and shift of midline structures (green line) to the right. The anterior horns of the lateral ventricles (hatched green overlay) are compressed and the posterior horn of the right lateral ventricle (red circle) is dilated.

C) INCORRECT:

Bleeding between the dura mater and the skull is known as epidural hemorrhage and is often due to traumatic injury to the middle meningeal artery. Epidural hemorrhage should be suspected in any patient with head trauma that causes loss of consciousness, followed by a lucid interval, and subsequent worsening with signs of increased ICP. CT scan of the head would show a characteristic lentiform (lens-shaped) hemorrhagic collection that does not cross suture lines. While this patient does have signs of increased ICP following a trauma, his CT findings suggest a different diagnosis.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT head (brain window: axial and coronal planes; bone window: axial plane)

A biconvex epidural hematoma (green overlay) with mass effect is seen in the left frontal region, adjacent to which is a small frontotemporal subdural hematoma (red overlay). A calvarial fracture (arrowheads) involves the left temporal and parietal bones.

D) INCORRECT:

Bleeding directly into the cerebral parenchyma, known as intracerebral hemorrhage, is typically caused by a spontaneous rupture of vessels secondary to structural changes of the vessel walls (e.g., chronic hypertension, cerebral amyloid angiopathy). Patients often present with headache and focal neurologic deficits such as hemiparesis. However, head trauma rarely leads to intracerebral hemorrhage, and signs of increased ICP are uncommon. Moreover, this patient's head CT is not consistent with intracerebral hemorrhage.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

A large hyperdense hematoma (green overlay) in the posterior aspect of the left cerebral hemisphere is accompanied by hypodense edema (red overlay), effacement of the occipital horn of the left lateral ventricle, and midline shift (dashed line and arrowheads).

ROH: right occipital horn

E) CORRECT:

Traumatic brain injury can cause subarachnoid hemorrhage, which is characterized by bleeding between the arachnoid mater and pia mater. Patients classically present with a sudden, severely painful headache, vomiting, loss of consciousness, and, in cases of severe hemorrhage, seizures. Head CT shows hyperdense signals in the area of the hemorrhage, which are seen in the basal cistern in this patient.
Image Description:

A subarachnoid hemorrhage is most commonly caused by the rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.
questions.hint: This type of intracranial hemorrhage can also occur in the absence of trauma in individuals with ruptured saccular aneurysms.

questions.text: Six days after admission to the intensive care unit, a 28-year-old man is evaluated for sudden onset hypertension, tachycardia, and muscle contractions of his extremities and back. He had a similar episode 3 hours ago, which resolved spontaneously after 10 minutes. Both episodes began shortly after he was repositioned in his bed. One week ago, he was brought to the emergency department in an unresponsive state after being involved in a motor vehicle accident. A CT scan of the head showed an epidural hematoma and the patient was transferred to the operating room for an emergency craniotomy with hematoma evacuation. Since his arrival to the intensive care unit after the procedure, he has remained intubated and mechanically ventilated, and his vital signs have been stable. His medical history is unavailable. He appears diaphoretic. His temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 155/min, and blood pressure is 160/94 mm Hg. Cardiac examination discloses no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Lungs are clear to auscultation. The pupils are equal and reactive bilaterally. The cranial surgical site is dry. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Paroxysmal sympathetic hyperactivity (PSH) is a complication of TBI that is thought to be caused by the loss of inhibition of the sympathetic nervous system due to cortical injury. It usually manifests about one week after the inciting event with recurrent episodes of hypertension, tachycardia, tachypnea, fever, diaphoresis, muscle spasms, and possibly dystonia with posturing. PSH episodes can occur spontaneously or be triggered by external stimulants, such as patient repositioning or extraction of the endotracheal tube. Episodes typically last up to 30 minutes and are self-limiting.

PSH is a clinical diagnosis. Other diagnostic tests (e.g., EEG, head CT/MRI) can be considered to rule out other diagnoses. Management is conservative and varies according to the constellation of symptoms. Opioids (e.g., morphine, fentanyl), sympatholytics (e.g., clonidine, propranolol), benzodiazepines (e.g., diazepam, lorazepam), and myorelaxants (e.g., dantrolene, baclofen) are commonly used to reduce symptoms of PSH.

B) INCORRECT:

Reflex epilepsy can manifest with episodes of dystonic posturing, hypertension, and tachycardia that are triggered by a vestibular stimulus (e.g., repositioning). However, diaphoresis and fever are not characteristic of reflex epilepsy.

C) INCORRECT:

Hospitalization, mechanical ventilation, and a history of recent surgery are risk factors for sepsis, which can manifest with fever, diaphoresis, and tachycardia. However, patients present with hypotension (due to septic shock), not hypertension, and experience constant, rapidly worsening symptoms rather than episodic symptoms triggered by repositioning. Furthermore, sepsis is not usually associated with dystonia.

D) INCORRECT:

A history of surgery and postoperative immobilization are risk factors for pulmonary embolism (PE), which can manifest with sudden-onset tachycardia, tachypnea, and (low-grade) fever. However, patients usually develop hypotension (due to pulmonary artery obstruction), not hypertension. Symptoms are usually persistent and are not triggered by repositioning. Furthermore, PE does not explain this patient's diaphoresis or dystonia.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients with TBI often develop elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) due to cerebral edema. Elevated ICP can induce a Cushing reflex, which manifests with hypertension, bradycardia (not tachycardia), and respiratory suppression. In addition, fever, diaphoresis, and dystonia are not characteristic of elevated ICP. Furthermore, patients with elevated ICP typically present with constant rather than episodic symptoms triggered by repositioning.
questions.hint: This patient's condition occurred as a complication of his traumatic brain injury (TBI).

questions.text:
A father brings his 11-month-old daughter to the emergency department one hour after he saw her fall off a bed from a height of 2 feet onto a hardwood floor. She immediately cried and never lost consciousness. After calming down, she has not vomited and is behaving normally.
The child is awake and alert, and she appears well. Examination reveals a bruise on the left frontal forehead but no signs of bruising elsewhere on her body.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Observe for a few hours and discharge home
Obtain plain radiographs of the skull

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A head CT should be done first when there is concern for a skull fracture. However, a full skeletal survey should be considered if child abuse is suspected or if the circumstances of the trauma are not consistent with the known developmental abilities of the child.

B) CORRECT:

Head trauma is a common reason for emergency department visits. Neuroimaging may expose the developing brain of a child to ionizing radiation that can lead to malignancies. Prediction rules identify patients for whom imaging is unnecessary.

No imaging is necessary for children <2 years of age who meet all of the following criteria:

• Normal mental status
• No scalp hematoma or only a hematoma in the frontal region
• No loss of consciousness or a loss of consciousness for no longer than 5 seconds
• Nonsevere mechanism of injury (e.g., a fall from <3 feet)
• No palpable skull fracture
• Normal behavior according to the parents

A child who meets all of these criteria may simply be observed for 4 to 6 hours after the injury, followed by discharge to home with instructions about warning signs (vomiting, lethargy, or altered mental status).

Key learning point: For a patient younger than 2 years who has a bruise over the frontal skull after a recent minor head trauma but who otherwise appears well, the most appropriate next step is to observe first without imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Plain radiographs of the skull can confirm fractures, but they give no direct information about intracranial brain injury.

D) INCORRECT:

A full skeletal survey should be considered if child abuse is suspected or if the circumstances of the trauma are not consistent with the known developmental abilities of the child. However, even in such cases, a head CT should be done first when there is concern for a skull fracture.

E) INCORRECT:

A brain MRI can detect brain injuries but is not the preferred initial imaging study in settings of trauma. Brain MRI is not as fast as CT and typically requires sedation.

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department (ED) by ambulance after falling, unhelmeted, from an all-terrain vehicle and sustaining a 45-second loss of consciousness. Emergency medical services personnel have placed her on a long board with cervical spine immobilization and report that she has been alert, with one episode of emesis.
On examination, the girl is crying and calling out for her mother. She has normal vital signs and a score of 15 on the Glasgow Coma Scale. Her breath sounds are equal bilaterally, and her peripheral pulses are strong. Her abdomen is soft and nontender. She has numerous abrasions on all four extremities but no obvious deformities. She also has a contusion on her forehead and an area of ecchymosis behind her left ear.
In addition to close monitoring, what is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain contrast CT of the head and cervical spine, and maintain cervical spine immobilization
Obtain noncontrast CT of the head and cervical spine, and maintain cervical spine immobilization
Maintain cervical spine immobilization, and observe for 2 to 4 hours in the ED with an oral challenge
Obtain noncontrast CT of the head after removing the cervical collar
Obtain MRI of the brain and cervical spine, and maintain cervical spine immobilization

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Noncontrast CT of the head is the reference standard for rapid detection of TBI and should be obtained in this patient.

B) CORRECT:

The likelihood of traumatic brain injury (TBI) in this patient is very high, given the severe mechanism of injury, loss of consciousness, postevent emesis, and discoloration behind the ear (Battle sign), which is highly suggestive of a basilar skull fracture.

Noncontrast CT of the head is the reference standard for rapid detection of TBI and should be obtained in this patient. Indications for such imaging include altered mental status, amnesia regarding the event, progressive headache, loss of consciousness, anisocoria, physical evidence of basilar skull fracture (seen in this patient), and repeated vomiting after the injury.

All children with significantly traumatic mechanisms of injury and signs of TBI (as in this case) should be assumed to have a cervical spine injury until proven otherwise. A cervical collar should remain in place to stabilize the cervical spine until injury is ruled out. Imaging options for the cervical spine include plain-film radiographs, CT, and MRI. Although CT does not provide a thorough screen for ligamentous injury, it can be used to evaluate for cervical spine fractures when adequate plain-film radiographs cannot be obtained. Plain-film radiographs, particularly open-mouth views, can be difficult to obtain in patients this young.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step in care for a young child who presents to the emergency department after a traumatic fall and has physical evidence suggestive of a basilar skull fracture but an otherwise normal physical examination is to obtain noncontrast CT of the head and cervical spine and maintain cervical spine immobilization.

C) INCORRECT:

Observation for a period of 2 to 4 hours postinjury as an initial step in management is only appropriate for children who meet all of the low-risk criteria for TBI according to the PECARN (Pediatric Emergency Care Applied Research Network) guidelines. For a child ≥2 years of age, low-risk TBI criteria include normal mental status, nonsevere mechanism of injury, no loss of consciousness, no vomiting, no headache, and no evidence of basilar skull fracture. This patient has both a history of losing consciousness and evidence of basilar skull fracture on examination. Observation alone is therefore not appropriate in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

All children with significantly traumatic mechanisms of injury and signs of TBI (as in this case) should be assumed to have a cervical spine injury until proven otherwise. A cervical collar should remain in place to stabilize the cervical spine until injury is ruled out.

E) INCORRECT:

MRI of the brain may detect bleeding or skull fracture, but it is less sensitive than CT for both of these conditions in the immediate postinjury period. MRI studies are also significantly longer in duration than noncontrast CT, and in young children, MRI usually requires sedation or anesthesia. In a child with concern for TBI but a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15, avoidance of sedative medications is optimal to facilitate close monitoring of neurologic status. MRI is excellent for obtaining nuanced information about axonal injury or ligamentous cervical spine injuries. These more detailed studies are often obtained on inpatient trauma victims once initial stabilization and triage have occurred.

questions.text:
A 5-month-old girl arrives in the emergency department (ED) unresponsive and accompanied by her father. He reports that she had multiple episodes of emesis earlier in the day and that, one hour ago, he started noticing repetitive movements of her arms and legs. She has no previous history of neurologic problems.
Her Glasgow Coma Scale score upon ED arrival is 9. Her pupils are equal and slowly reactive. A funduscopic examination is conducted (figure), and a CT scan of the head is obtained.
Which one of the following findings is most likely to be seen on this patient's CT scan?

choices.text: Widening of the bifrontal and anterior interhemispheric cerebrospinal fluid spaces
Subtle low densities within the anterior and medial parts of the temporal lobe

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although epidural hematoma can occur from nonaccidental trauma, it is usually due to a single, local strike to the head rather than to a series of shakes. As a result, it is not associated with retinal hemorrhages on fundoscopic examination.

B) INCORRECT:

Enlargement of the subarachnoid spaces, with widening of the bifrontal and anterior interhemispheric cerebrospinal fluid spaces, is associated with benign macrocephaly. This finding may be picked up incidentally or during a workup for macrocephaly, especially in a patient with a family history of large heads.

C) INCORRECT:

A diffuse intrinsic pontine glioma involves the brainstem and usually manifests with cranial nerve palsies, ataxia, and hydrocephalus; symptom onset is not typically acute.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's funduscopic examination shows diffuse retinal hemorrhages of varying ages, with a circumpapillary retinal ridge considered pathognomonic for nonaccidental traumatic brain injury (shaken-baby syndrome). When shaken repeatedly, an infant’s brain shifts back and forth within the skull, tearing the bridging veins that lie beneath the dura mater and resulting in a characteristic subdural bleeding pattern. A Glasgow Coma Scale score of 9 places this patient in the moderate-to-severe range of traumatic brain injury. Subdural hematoma is the most likely finding on a CT scan of the head, as it is associated with retinal hemorrhages in this clinical context.

Key learning point: In an infant, the combination of diminished mental status, evidence of retinal hemorrhages on funduscopic examination, and subdural hematomas on CT scan is consistent with nonaccidental traumatic brain injury.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes encephalitis can be seen on cranial CT, with and without contrast enhancement, as subtle low densities within the anterior and medial parts of the temporal lobe. Herpes encephalitis may have associated hemorrhages but usually without retinal involvement.

questions.text: A 28-year-old construction worker presents to the emergency department 3 hours after falling from scaffolding. Coworkers report that he was unconscious for approximately 90 seconds but was alert when EMS arrived. He now has a headache and reports no memory of the fall or the 30 minutes preceding it. Vital signs are normal, and neurological examination shows no focal deficits. He is alert and oriented with a Glasgow coma scale score of 15. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge home with head injury instructions

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient has risk factors for intracranial injury, including loss of consciousness and retrograde amnesia, warranting further evaluation before discharge to ensure patient safety.

B) INCORRECT:

While cervical spine injury should be considered based on the trauma mechanism, assessing for intracranial injury takes priority for this patient because of the neurological symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

Routine seizure prophylaxis is not indicated in mild traumatic brain injury without evidence of intracranial pathology or seizure activity.

D) INCORRECT:

Further diagnostic assessment must be performed before determining the need for observation or discharge.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has mild traumatic brain injury with brief loss of consciousness and retrograde amnesia. These clinical features, combined with the mechanism of injury (fall from height), indicate an increased risk for intracranial lesions. Head CT without contrast is indicated to rule out surgically significant intracranial injuries before determining disposition.

questions.text: A 28-year-old construction worker presents to the emergency department 4 hours after falling backwards from scaffolding and striking his head on concrete. He was wearing a hard hat and initially walked to the supervisor's office but became confused about his whereabouts. His coworkers report that he asked the same questions repeatedly for about 45 minutes after the incident. On arrival, his Glasgow coma scale score is 15, vital signs are normal, and he has a mild headache but denies nausea or vomiting. Physical examination shows a 2-cm laceration on his occipital scalp with no signs of basilar skull fracture. He cannot recall the 90 minutes before his fall but remembers events after the paramedics arrived. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Discharge home with head injury precautions
Observe for 6 hours then discharge if neurologically stable

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Before considering discharge, further evaluation is indicated to ensure that important clinical risk factors necessitating immediate assessment are not overlooked.

B) INCORRECT:

While cervical spine imaging can be important in trauma, prioritizing the assessment of other critical concerns takes precedence for this patient. Further steps should focus on the more urgent potential injuries.

C) INCORRECT:

This imaging modality is not routinely used for initial assessment in acute head trauma due to limited availability and less optimal detection of certain acute injuries. Established, validated protocols favor alternative imaging techniques for first-line evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Monitoring without definitive diagnostic evaluation may delay the identification of serious injuries. Current guidelines recommend completing necessary assessments prior to deciding on observation or discharge.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- According to the Canadian CT head rule, patients with retrograde amnesia lasting ≥ 30 minutes meet medium-risk criteria for neuroimaging. This patient's 90 minutes of retrograde amnesia places them at significant risk for traumatic intracranial lesions. CT head without contrast is the first-line imaging modality to evaluate for intracranial hemorrhage and other structural abnormalities in traumatic brain injury.
